questions.text: A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Henoch-Schonlein purpura

 

The combination of palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain resulting from arthritis, and urinary findings of hematuria and proteinuria is characteristic of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder characterized by a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, polyarthralgia, and renal abnormalities. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years.

 

The patient may present with the following clinical features:

 

  • Skin lesions- These typically involve the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs, as well as the buttocks.
  • Pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding are examples of abdominal manifestations.
  • Renal manifestations include hematuria, nephritic syndrome, and nephrotic syndrome. Adults have more severe renal manifestations. Some patients develop a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura: typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding, without joint pain or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Dengue fever: Dengue fever is a viral illness that typically presents with fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Churg-Strauss syndrome is a rare systemic autoimmune disease that typically presents with asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis, often involving multiple organs. While arthritis may be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome, palpable purpura is uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schonlein purpura is characterized by the presence of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal involvement, typically manifesting as hematuria and proteinuria. It is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly affecting children and is distinguished by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in affected tissues.

questions.text: A patient has adult respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is the action of IL-8 in the pathogenesis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neutrophil activation

 

In the pathogenesis of Adult Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), Interleukin-8 (IL-8) plays a crucial role as a potent chemokine that specifically attracts and activates neutrophils.

 

Neutrophil activation is a critical step in the inflammatory cascade that exacerbates endothelial injury and subsequent lung damage in ARDS. Neutrophils, once activated, release proteases, reactive oxygen species, and other inflammatory mediators that contribute to the damage of the alveolar-capillary membrane, further aggravating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial injury: While endothelial injury is an important early event in ARDS, it is not directly caused by IL-8. Instead, endothelial injury triggers the release of cytokines, including IL-8, which then leads to neutrophil recruitment and activation.

 

Option C. Fibrin deposition: Fibrin deposition is a downstream event in ARDS and is a result of the damage caused by neutrophil activation and endothelial injury. IL-8 indirectly contributes to this through its role in neutrophil activation, but it is not directly responsible for fibrin deposition.

 

Option D. Macrophage activation: While macrophages are involved in the inflammatory response in ARDS, IL-8 primarily targets neutrophils, not macrophages. IL-8's main action is to attract and activate neutrophils rather than macrophages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-8 is a key mediator in ARDS that promotes neutrophil activation, which plays a major role in the amplification of inflammation and lung injury in the disease process.

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic feature of hemolysis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased haptoglobin

 

Characteristic feature of hemolysis is decreased haptoglobin. Serum haptoglobin levels are decreased in hemolytic anemias.

 

There are two Types of hemolysis with following features -  

 

  • Intravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs mainly within the blood vessels

 

Features:

  • Decreased haptoglobin
  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase
  • Hemoglobinuria
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • Extravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs in spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph nodes

 

Features:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Variable decreases in plasma haptoglobin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reticulocytopenia: Hemolysis typically causes reticulocytosis, not reticulocytopenia.

 

Option C. Neutropenia: Hemolysis affects red blood cells, not neutrophils.

 

Option D. Increased conjugated bilirubin: Hemolysis usually increases unconjugated bilirubin due to the breakdown of red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased haptoglobin is a characteristic feature of hemolysis, distinguishing it from other conditions.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Entameoba histolytica

 

Flask shaped ulcers are classically seen in amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica.

 

 

The most typical form of amoebic infection, amoebic colitis, starts as a tiny region of necrosis of mucosa that may ulcerate. These ulcerative lesions may grow, develop ulcer edge undermining from trophozoite lytic action, and have a necrotic bed. Due to their structure, such chronic amoebic ulcers are called flask-shaped ulcers (narrow neck and broad base). In addition to the presence of Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites, the ulcer's edge exhibits an inflammatory response with an admixture of polymorphonuclear and mononuclear cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giardia lamblia: Causes giardiasis, affecting the small intestine and leading to malabsorption and diarrhea but not flask-shaped ulcers.

 

Option C. Helicobacter pylori: Associated with gastric and duodenal ulcers, not typically flask-shaped or located in the colon.

 

Option D. Entamoeba vermicularis: Incorrect nomenclature; possibly meant to refer to a helminth such as Enterobius vermicularis, which causes pinworm infections and does not lead to ulcer formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica is the cause of flask-shaped ulcers in the colon, distinguishing it from other intestinal pathogens due to its invasive capabilities and the characteristic morphology of the ulcers it creates. Understanding these features helps in the differential diagnosis of dysentery and guides appropriate treatment and management strategies.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in a female with dysuria and vesicles for which she underwent an examination that revealed the presence of cells as shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The image shown is a Tzanck smear, which is often used to diagnose infections caused by herpes viruses. The Tzanck smear reveals characteristic nuclear changes, including nuclear molding, margination of chromatin, and multinucleated giant cells, which are hallmark findings in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.

 

Patients with HSV typically present with vesicular lesions on the genitalia accompanied by dysuria and pain. The infection involves the fusion of epithelial cells, leading to the appearance of multinucleated giant cells, a distinctive feature seen on Tzanck smears.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. It presents with frothy discharge and vaginal itching but does not produce vesicular lesions or the cytological features seen in HSV.

 

Option C. Human papilloma virus (HPV): HPV causes genital warts and is associated with cervical dysplasia and cancer. It does not produce vesicular lesions or characteristic changes like multinucleated giant cells seen in HSV.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections are characterized by large cells with prominent intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions, often described as "owl's eye" appearance. This differs from the nuclear molding and margination seen in HSV infections.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus infection is identified by multinucleated giant cells, nuclear molding, and margination on Tzanck smear, distinguishing it from other genital infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with painful oral mucosal lesions and blisters on her skin. A biopsy is performed, and direct immunofluorescence microscopy is used to examine the skin specimen. Based on this finding, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by painful mucosal lesions and skin blisters.

 

The direct immunofluorescence (DIF) image shows a characteristic "fishnet" or "chicken-wire" pattern due to IgG antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3, which are components of the desmosomes that connect epidermal cells.

 

The disruption of these desmosomes leads to acantholysis and intraepidermal blister formation, as seen in pemphigus vulgaris. The presence of painful oral lesions further supports this diagnosis, as they are commonly seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid: This condition also presents with blisters but typically in older patients without mucosal involvement. DIF shows a linear pattern of IgG and C3 at the basement membrane zone, not the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is characterized by intensely pruritic vesicles and papules, typically on extensor surfaces. DIF shows granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, which is different from the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option D. Lupus vulgaris: This is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting with slow-growing reddish-brown nodules, not blisters. It does not show a fishnet pattern on DIF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris presents with painful oral lesions and skin blisters, and its hallmark DIF finding is the fishnet pattern due to antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils. Which of the following translocation is seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) t (9:22)

 

Massive splenomegaly and a peripheral smear showing leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils are symptoms of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This condition is characterized by a translocation between t (9;22).

 

CML is classified as a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused by a translocation between BCR (on chromosome 22) and ABL (on chromosome 9) to form a fusion gene. It leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is characteristic of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. t (8;22): Associated with Burkitt lymphoma involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8.

 

Option C. t (15;17): Associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), involving the PML and RARA genes.

 

Option D. t (8;14): Also associated with Burkitt lymphoma, involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the IgH locus on chromosome 14.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The translocation t(9;22) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which produces the BCR-ABL fusion gene responsible for the disease's pathogenesis.

choices.text: Webbing of hands and toes are associated with risk of visceral anomalies
Noonan syndrome is more associated with cardiac defects
Absence of neck webbing is associated with higher risk of coarctation of aorta
Webbing of neck is associated with higher risk of cardiac anomalies

questions.text: Which amongst the following is true about Turner's syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Webbing of neck is associated with higher risk of cardiac anomalies

 

In Turner's syndrome, webbing of the neck is associated with a higher risk of cardiac anomalies.

 

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome and is characterized primarily by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Webbing of hands and toes are associated with risk of visceral anomalies: Webbing of hands and toes is not specifically associated with Turner syndrome, nor is it a marker for visceral anomalies. Webbing or syndactyly is more commonly seen in other congenital conditions and does not relate directly to the risk of cardiac anomalies in Turner syndrome.

 

Option B. Noonan syndrome is more associated with cardiac defects: While Noonan syndrome does indeed have a high association with cardiac defects, the question pertains specifically to Turner syndrome. Noonan syndrome and Turner syndrome have some overlapping features, but Noonan syndrome is a distinct genetic disorder that is not related to the X chromosome abnormalities seen in Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Absence of neck webbing is associated with higher risk of coarctation of aorta: This statement is incorrect. In Turner syndrome, the presence, not the absence, of neck webbing is associated with a higher risk of coarctation of the aorta and other cardiac anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Turner syndrome, the presence of neck webbing is significantly associated with an increased risk of cardiac anomalies, particularly coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition, Pg no 318-319

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulin

 

Tubulin is a part of microtubules and is not an intermediate filament.

 

The intermediate filaments comprise the major component of the cytoskeleton and consist of five major subgroups—vimentin, keratins, desmin, neurofilaments, and glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)—and a small number of minor subgroups (e.g., nestin, peripherin).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vimentin: Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein commonly found in cells of mesenchymal origin. It helps maintain cellular integrity and provides resistance to stress.

 

Option C. Desmin: Desmin is an intermediate filament protein found predominantly in muscle cells. It is crucial for maintaining the structural integrity of muscle cells by linking the cytoskeletal network to the sarcomere.

 

Option D. Neurofilament: Neurofilaments are intermediate filaments found in neurons. They are important for maintaining the shape and strength of nerve cells and play a role in the conduction of nerve impulses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulin is not an intermediate filament; it is a protein that forms microtubules, which are essential for cell shape, motility, and division. Intermediate filaments, such as vimentin, desmin, and neurofilaments, provide mechanical support and structural integrity to cells.

choices.text: Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°C with a shelf life of 5 days
Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months
Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol and saline is stored between -5°C to -15 °C with a shelf life of 5 weeks
Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15° C with a shelf life of 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about blood products? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelets is stored between 20° C to 24° C with a shelf life of 5 days

 

Platelets can be stored at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 24°C, and they have a shelf life of 5 days (with continuous agitation) 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months: This statement is incorrect because cryoprecipitate is typically stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C with a shelf life of 1 year. Cryoprecipitate is rich in clotting factors like fibrinogen, Factor VIII, and von Willebrand factor.

 

Option C. Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol, and saline is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 5 weeks: This statement is incorrect. Packed red blood cells stored with solutions like SAGM (Saline, Adenine, Glucose, Mannitol) are typically stored at temperatures between 2°C to 6°C, not -5°C to -15°C, and they have a shelf life of up to 42 days, not 5 weeks.

 

Option D. Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 2 years: This statement is incorrect. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is usually stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C and has a shelf life of 1 year.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-coagulants solution and shelf life

questions.text: Which of the following is a tool used in gene editing: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CRISPR

 

The core technologies now most commonly used to facilitate genome editing are -

 

1. Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9) – CRISPs are guide RNAS. By delivering the Cas9 nuclease complexed with a synthetic guide RNA (gRNA) into a cell, the cell's genome can be cut at a desired location, allowing existing genes to be removed and/or new ones added in vivo.

 

 

2. Transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENs)

 

3. Zinc-finger nucleases (ZFNs)

 

4. Homing endonucleases or meganucleases.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Big data: Refers to the large volume of data that can be analyzed to reveal patterns, trends, and associations, especially relating to human behavior and interactions, but it is not a tool for gene editing.

 

Option C. Gene Xpert: Is a diagnostic tool used to detect genetic material from specific pathogens (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis) and is not related to gene editing.

 

Option D. GWAS (Genome-Wide Association Studies): Involves scanning genomes from many different people to find genetic markers associated with specific diseases. While related to genetics, it is not a tool for directly editing genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR is a powerful gene editing tool that enables precise modifications of the genome and is used extensively in genetic research and therapeutic applications.

questions.text: In which urinary components is Tamm Horsfall protein present? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) urine cast

 

Tamm Horsfall protein is present in urine cast.

 

Tamm-Horsfall protein, also known as uromodulin, is a glycoprotein produced by the cells lining the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidneys. It is the most abundant protein found in normal human urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urine Crystal: Urine crystals are solid particles found in urine, often composed of substances like calcium oxalate, uric acid, or struvite. They are not related to Tamm-Horsfall protein.

 

Option C. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is a yellow compound that occurs in the normal catabolic pathway that breaks down heme in vertebrates. It is not associated with Tamm-Horsfall protein.

 

Option D. Bile Salts: Bile salts are components of bile, which aid in the digestion of fats. They are not found in urine and are not related to Tamm-Horsfall protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamm-Horsfall protein (uromodulin) is present in urine casts and is the most abundant protein found in normal human urine.

questions.text: A patient with gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological symptoms underwent a blood examination whose peripheral smear image is provided here. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abetalipoproteinemia

 

The image provided shows red blood cells with irregular, spiky projections, known as acanthocytes.

 

Acanthocytes (also known as a spur cell) are characterized by asymmetrical and irregular projections, unlike echinocytes, which have evenly spaced projections.

 

Acanthocytes are strongly associated with abetalipoproteinemia, a rare disorder caused by a defect in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein, leading to impaired fat absorption and deficiency of lipoproteins like LDL and VLDL. Echinocytes are typically observed in conditions like uremia or burn injuries.

 

 

Abetalipoproteinemia presents with a combination of gastrointestinal symptoms (such as malabsorption) and neurological symptoms (like ataxia and neuropathy) due to deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins, especially vitamin E. The presence of acanthocytes in the blood smear is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uremia: Uremia can lead to the formation of burr cells (echinocytes), which have regularly spaced projections. However, these projections are symmetrical and differ from the irregular projections seen in acanthocytes.

 

Option B. Burns: Burn injuries can also lead to the formation of burr cells (echinocytes) due to alterations in red cell membrane structure caused by thermal damage. The symmetrical projections of echinocytes are distinct from the asymmetrical projections of acanthocytes.

 

Option D. Hereditary spherocytosis: This condition is characterized by spherical red blood cells (spherocytes) due to a defect in the red cell membrane proteins. It does not present with spiky projections like acanthocytes, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acanthocytes, or spur cells, are red blood cells with irregular, spiky projections associated with abetalipoproteinemia, a disorder characterized by fat malabsorption, vitamin deficiencies, and neurological symptoms.

choices.text: Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
Need antigen processing and presentation for it recognition

questions.text: Which of the following about γδ T-cells is incorrect? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Need antigen processing and presentation for it recognition

 

γδ T-cells do not need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition.

 

There are two types of T cells: γδ T-cells and αβ T-cells.

 

  • The functions of γδ T-cells:
    • Provide protection against mycobacteria by direct killing of infected macrophages
    • Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
    • Plays a role in maintaining self-tolerance
    • Capable of recognizing and lying diverse cancers in an MHC-unrestricted manner
  • The αβ TCR recognizes peptide antigens that are displayed by major histocompatibility complex (MHC. molecules on the surfaces of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). By limiting the specificity of T cells for peptides displayed by cell surface MHC molecules, called MHC restriction, the immune system ensures that T cells see only cell-associated antigens (e.g., those derived from microbes in cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin: This is correct and one of the key functions of γδ T-cells.

 

Option C. Direct killing of infected macrophages: This is correct, as γδ T-cells can directly target and kill infected cells.

 

Option D. Provide protection against mycobacteria: This is correct; γδ T-cells play an important role in defense against mycobacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

γδ T-cells do not require antigen processing and presentation by MHC molecules for their recognition, unlike αβ T-cells, making them unique in their ability to directly recognize and respond to a variety of antigens.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 352-353

questions.text: A middle aged lady presented with difficulty in swallowing food and gritty sensation in the eyes. She is also having autoantibodies in her blood sample. What is the likely diagnosis in her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sjogren syndrome

 

Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) due to lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of the exocrine glands. The gritty sensation in the eyes and difficulty in swallowing food (which can be due to dry mouth and esophageal involvement) are classic symptoms. The presence of autoantibodies, such as anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB, supports the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus): While SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms and autoantibodies, dry eyes and dry mouth are less specific for SLE compared to Sjogren syndrome.

 

Option B. Systemic sclerosis: This condition involves fibrosis and hardening of the skin and internal organs, and while it can cause difficulty swallowing due to esophageal involvement, it is not primarily associated with dry eyes.

 

Option D. Mixed connective tissue disorder (MCTD): MCTD is characterized by features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, and it can include autoantibodies like anti-U1 RNP. However, the specific symptoms of dry eyes and dry mouth are more indicative of Sjogren syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth due to autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands, often accompanied by specific autoantibodies.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of agranulocytosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug toxicity

 

Drug toxicity is the most common cause of agranulocytosis. Agranulocytosis is a condition in which there is a severe decrease in the number of white blood cells called granulocytes, which are responsible for fighting bacterial infections. Certain medications, such as chemotherapy drugs, antibiotics, antipsychotics, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), can cause agranulocytosis as a side effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marrow infiltration: While it can cause agranulocytosis, it is less common than drug-induced cases.

 

Option B. Autoimmune: Can lead to agranulocytosis through immune-mediated destruction of neutrophils but is also less frequent than drug toxicity.

 

Option D. Radiation exposure: Can suppress bone marrow but typically in the context of higher and prolonged exposures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of agranulocytosis include:

 

  • Inadequate or ineffective granulopoiesis
  • Suppression of hematopoietic stem cells - aplastic anemia, infiltrative marrow disorders
  • Suppression of committed granulocytic precursors
  • Ineffective hematopoiesis - megaloblastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Congenital conditions - Kostmann syndrome
  • Increased destruction or sequestration of neutrophils -
  • Immunological injury to neutrophils - idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus, drug exposure
  • Increased peripheral utilization - bacterial, fungal, or rickettsial infections
  • Splenomegaly

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of Alzheimer disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amyloid beta plaque

 

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of senile dementia, characterized by the accumulation of amyloid beta plaques in the brain. These plaques are abnormal clumps of protein that disrupt cell function and are a hallmark of Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

The presence of amyloid beta plaques contributes to neurodegeneration, synaptic dysfunction, and cognitive decline observed in Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha synuclein: This protein is associated with Parkinson’s disease and Lewy body dementia, where it forms abnormal aggregates called Lewy bodies. It is not a marker for Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Option C. Glial fibrillary associated protein: This protein is found in astrocytes and is commonly associated with gliosis, not specifically with Alzheimer’s disease. It is not a marker for Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

Option D. Desmin: Desmin is an intermediate filament protein found in muscle tissue and is related to muscle disorders, not neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloid beta plaque is a key pathological marker of Alzheimer’s disease, contributing significantly to the neurodegenerative changes seen in this condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffering from persistent fatigue and lymph node enlargement visits the outpatient department. Examination of his peripheral smear reveals the presence of smudge cells. To further establish a diagnosis, what additional investigations will you conduct? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

An elderly man presenting with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy and revelation of smudge cells on peripheral smear suggests a diagnosis of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. Flow cytometry is the investigation of choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is typically used for detecting specific genetic mutations or translocations but is not the primary diagnostic tool for CLL.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH is used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities, such as deletions or translocations. While useful, it is not the first-line investigation for diagnosing CLL.

 

Option D. Cytogenetics: Cytogenetic analysis can reveal chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL, such as deletion 13q, but is typically used in conjunction with other tests like flow cytometry.

 

Educational Objective:


Flow cytometry is the primary diagnostic tool for confirming Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, particularly in cases where smudge cells are identified on a peripheral smear.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with nausea, vomiting, edema and ascites. He had severely deranged liver function tests and a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma was diagnosed. Which of the following is important in the pathogenesis of this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aflatoxin

 

Aflatoxin, produced by the fungus Aspergillus flavus, is a potent hepatotoxin and carcinogen. Chronic exposure to aflatoxin is strongly associated with the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), particularly in regions where food contamination with this toxin is common. Aflatoxin causes mutations in the p53 tumor suppressor gene, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation and cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benzene: Benzene is primarily associated with hematological malignancies such as leukemia, not hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option B. Arsenic: Chronic arsenic exposure is linked to skin cancer, lung cancer, and bladder cancer, but it is not a primary cause of HCC.

 

Option D. Vinyl chloride: Vinyl chloride exposure is associated with angiosarcoma of the liver, a different type of liver cancer, rather than hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is an intranuclear immuno-histochemistry marker for neuroendocrine tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) INSM

 

Intranuclear immunohistochemistry markers are specifically located within the nucleus of the cell, unlike cytoplasmic or membranous markers.

 

INSM (Insulinoma Associated Protein 1) is a novel intranuclear marker used for the detection of neuroendocrine tumors. It is particularly useful in diagnosing various types of neuroendocrine tumors, including small cell carcinoma of the lung, medullary thyroid cancer, Merkel cell carcinoma, and paraganglioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromogranin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option B. NCAM: Incorrect because it is a membranous marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option C. Synaptophysin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

INSM is an intranuclear marker for neuroendocrine tumors, distinguishing it from other cytoplasmic or membranous markers such as Chromogranin, NCAM, and Synaptophysin.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. General examination showed pallor and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed Hb level- 3 gm/dI, TLC-1500/microL, platelet count - 15000/microL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and the reticulocyte count is 0.5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis? (Hb- Hemoglobin, TLC- Total leucocyte count)? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia

 

The given clinical scenario showing a young male with gum bleeding, fever, pancytopenia, and a low reticulocyte count with bone marrow showing fatty streaks and no immature cells is suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Key Diagnostic Features of Aplastic Anemia:

 

  • Pancytopenia (low Hb, WBC, and platelets)
  • Hypocellular (fatty) bone marrow
  • No immature/blast cells
  • Low reticulocyte count (indicates bone marrow failure)
  • Macrocytes due to ineffective hematopoiesis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH is characterized by hemolysis, hemoglobinuria (especially in the morning), and thrombosis. The presentation of pancytopenia with bone marrow aplasia is more suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Option C. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS are a diverse group of hematopoietic clonal stem cell disorders characterized by abnormal development of various marrow elements (i.e., dysmyelopoiesis), cytopenias, cellular marrow, and ineffective blood cell formation.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis can cause pancytopenia if the bone marrow is involved, but the bone marrow would show granulomas rather than the fatty streaks and absence of immature cells seen in aplastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pancytopenia

 

I. Aplastic anemia

 

II. Pancytopenia with normal or increased marrow cellularity

 

e.g.

 

  1.  Myelodysplastic syndromes
  2. Hypersplenism
  3.  Megaloblastic anemia

 

III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

 

IV. Bone marrow infiltrations

 

e.g:

 

  1. Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)
  2. Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies
  3. Storage diseases
  4. Osteopetrosis
  5. Myelofibrosis

questions.text: Match the mode of inheritance with the disorder in the appropriate column: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B

 

1. Autosomal Dominant -  D. Myotonia dystrophica

  • Autosomal dominant disorders are typically inherited from one affected parent. Myotonia dystrophica, characterized by muscle stiffness and other systemic symptoms, exhibits this pattern of inheritance.

 

2. X-Linked Recessive – A. Duchene Muscular Dystrophy

  • X-linked recessive disorders mainly affect males and are passed on by carrier mothers. Duchene Muscular Dystrophy, which leads to muscle degeneration and weakness, is a classic example.

 

3. Autosomal Recessive – C. Cystic fibrosis

  • Autosomal recessive disorders require both parents to pass on a faulty gene. Cystic fibrosis, which causes severe damage to the respiratory and digestive systems, is inherited this way.

 

4. Mitochondrial – B. Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy (Leber's disease)

  • Mitochondrial diseases are inherited through mutations in mitochondrial DNA, typically passed from mother to all offspring. Leber's disease leads to sudden vision loss primarily in young adults.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Each genetic disorder has a specific pattern of inheritance that affects its transmission and manifestation in individuals.

questions.text: Identify the given condition: (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Given histology image shows a suprabasal blister which points to a diagnosis of Pemphigus Vulgaris.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leprosy: Tuberculoid leprosy (paucibacillary) will show granulomatous lesions while lepromatous lesions (multibacillary) shows lipid-laden macrophages (lepra cells) filled with masses (globi) of acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides: Lower portion of the epidermis contains hyperchromatic enlarged lymphocytes. Pautrier’s microabscesses may be seen which are intradermal clusters of atypical lymphoid cells.

 

 

Option D. Visceral Leishmaniasis: Visceral Leishmaniasis shows skin lesion with abundant amastigotes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by suprabasal blisters and a row of tombstone appearance on histology, with a fishnet pattern on direct immunofluorescence due to IgG deposition.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 2307-2308

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leuko-reduced RBCs

 

The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such reactions can be prevented by using leuko-reduced RBCs

 

Fever (elevation of temperature by 1º C or 2º F) , chills, or rigors resulting from cytokines released by leukocyte in transfused red cell or platelet components is called as non-hemolytic febrile transfusion reaction. It is a diagnosis of exclusion, as hemolytic and septic reactions can present similarly.

 

Prevention –

 

  1. Pre-storage leukoreduction
  2. Acetaminophen if persistent fever
  3. Routine pretreatment with acetaminophen
  4. Use of platelet additive solution
  5. Plasma reduced or washed products if severe reactions
  6. Restrictive transfusion approach in high-risk patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics are not used to prevent transfusion reactions. They are used to treat bacterial infections and would not be effective in preventing FNHTR, which is not caused by bacterial contamination.

 

Option C. Irradiation: Irradiation of blood products is used to prevent transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GvHD), a different type of transfusion reaction, but it does not prevent FNHTR.

 

Option D. Washed RBCs: Washing RBCs removes plasma proteins and is used to prevent allergic reactions in patients with a history of severe allergic transfusion reactions, but it is not specifically aimed at preventing FNHTR. However, washed products can be used if the FNHTR is severe or recurrent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leuko-reduced RBCs are the preferred method to reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR), especially in patients requiring frequent transfusions like those with thalassemia.

 

  • FNHTRs are commonly due to cytokines released from donor leukocytes or recipient antibodies against donor leukocytes.
  • Leukoreduction removes most white blood cells from the blood product, thereby:
    • Reducing cytokine accumulation
    • Lowering risk of FNHTRs
    • Also helps prevent HLA alloimmunization and CMV transmission

questions.text: All of the following conditions are related to the same core pathology except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

 

Alzheimer's disease is a 3-amyloidopathy characterized by the accumulation of Aβ amyloid protein not an alpha-synucleinopathy.

 

Alpha-synucleinopathies:  A neurodegenerative disorders displaying an altered α-synuclein (αS) in the brain tissue and incorporates clinical entities such as Parkinson disease (PD), PD with dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies, and multiple-system atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parkinson's disease: An alpha-synucleinopathy characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein in Lewy bodies within the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Lewy body dementia: Another alpha-synucleinopathy where alpha-synuclein aggregates are found in Lewy bodies within the cortical and subcortical areas of the brain.

 

Option D. Multisystem atrophy: A neurodegenerative disorder also categorized as an alpha-synucleinopathy, where alpha-synuclein accumulates in glial cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alzheimer's disease is characterized by the accumulation of β-amyloid and tau proteins, differentiating it from alpha-synucleinopathies like Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and multisystem atrophy.

choices.text: Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin
Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+
Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum
Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

 

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is characterized by the presence of Reed Sternberg cells, which are of B cell origin. These cells typically express CD30 and PAX 5 markers. The nodular sclerosis subtype of HL often involves the mediastinum, where Reed Sternberg cells are referred to as lacunar cells due to their unique appearance in this subtype. However, the statement that the commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring is incorrect. The Waldeyer ring is more commonly involved in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). HL typically affects the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells, the hallmark of Hodgkin lymphoma, originate from B cells.

 

Option B. Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells express CD30 and PAX 5 markers, which are used in diagnosing Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum: Correct. The nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma frequently involves the mediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin lymphoma typically involves the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes. The involvement of the Waldeyer ring is more characteristic of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text:
Identify true statements about familial adenomatous polyposis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Autosomal recessive inheritance
  2. If not treated, all cases progress to adenocarcinoma colon.
  3. KRAS mutations cause familial adenomatous polyposis
  4. It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is a hereditary condition characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum, often numbering in the hundreds to thousands. The condition is caused by mutations in the APC gene (chromosome 5q), leading to autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

True Statements:

 

Statement 2: If not treated, all cases of FAP will progress to colorectal adenocarcinoma. This is because the polyps have a high potential to become malignant if not removed or if the patient does not undergo a prophylactic colectomy.

 

Statement 4: FAP is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium, which is often used as a marker for the condition, especially in screening family members.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1: FAP is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, not autosomal recessive. This means that a single copy of the mutated APC gene can cause the disease.

 

Statement 3: FAP is primarily caused by mutations in the APC gene, not KRAS. While KRAS mutations are involved in colorectal cancer progression, they are not the cause of FAP.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient with a midline neck swelling and histopathological findings of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on biopsy as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Papillary carcinoma

 

The presence of empty appearing nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

 

  • Histological Appearance: Papillary carcinoma has a papillary growth pattern with branching papillae composed of fibrovascular stalks and cuboidal epithelial cells.
  • Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei: Papillary carcinoma cells have distinct Orphan Annie eye nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and an optically clear or empty appearance.
  • Psammoma Bodies: Papillary carcinoma often contains psammoma bodies, which are concentrically calcified structures found within the papillae.
  • Lymphatic Invasion: Papillary carcinoma commonly exhibits lymphatic invasion; involvement of blood vessels is uncommon.
  • Genetic Alterations: Papillary carcinoma is associated with specific genetic changes, including gene rearrangements like RET/PTC and NTRK1, as well as BRAF gene mutations.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular carcinoma: This is incorrect. Follicular carcinoma typically presents with a different histological pattern, characterized by small follicles. It does not exhibit Orphan Annie eye nuclei, which are specific to papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Toxic nodular goitre: This is incorrect. Toxic nodular goitre, or multinodular goitre, is a benign condition and does not present with Orphan Annie eye nuclei or the other specific histological features of papillary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma: This is incorrect. Medullary carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and is characterized by amyloid deposits and the presence of calcitonin, rather than the histological features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on histopathological examination is a key diagnostic feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which immunoglobulin? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE

 

The given clinical features suggest a anaphylactic reaction, a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, and is mediated by immunoglobulin E.

 

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies.

 

It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals.

 

Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing. It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (such as the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g. peanuts, shellfish) or insect toxins (e.g. those in bee venom).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is mainly involved in mucosal immunity and does not play a primary role in type I hypersensitivity or anaphylactic reactions.

 

Option C. IgM: IgM is the first antibody produced during an initial immune response but is not involved in allergic or type I hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is involved in various immune responses, including type II and type III hypersensitivity reactions, but not in the immediate hypersensitivity reaction that leads to anaphylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgE is the immunoglobulin responsible for mediating type I hypersensitivity reactions, such as anaphylaxis, which can occur in response to bee stings or other allergens.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 373

questions.text: A patient had enlarging nodules present on his scalp. He was taking prednisolone, mycophenolate mofetil, and tacrolimus. His clinical lesion and the histopathological lesion are shown alongside. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malakoplakia

 

The patient's clinical history and biopsy findings suggest a diagnosis of Malakoplakia. Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous condition that is often associated with immunosuppressive states, such as in patients taking medications like prednisolone, mycophenolate, and tacrolimus.

 

The characteristic histopathological feature of Malakoplakia is the presence of Michaelis-Guttmann bodies, which are basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions with a "targetoid" appearance seen in macrophages.

 

These bodies result from incomplete phagocytosis and subsequent calcium and iron deposition.

 

Malakoplakia commonly affects the urinary bladder but can also present in other organs, including the skin, as seen in this patient with scalp lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis would typically present with caseating granulomas, which are not seen in the provided histopathological image. The characteristic Michaelis-Guttmann bodies in this image rule out tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Pyoderma gangrenosum: This condition is usually associated with painful ulcerative skin lesions and does not present with the histopathological findings seen here. Pyoderma gangrenosum is not associated with Michaelis-Guttmann bodies.

 

Option D. Drug-induced lesion: Drug-induced skin lesions generally present with nonspecific inflammation or necrosis rather than granulomatous inflammation with the distinct Michaelis-Guttmann bodies characteristic of Malakoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous condition marked by Michaelis-Guttmann bodies and is often seen in immunosuppressed patients. It can affect organs beyond the urinary bladder, including the skin.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are caused by high-risk strains of Human Papilloma virus except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papillomatosis

 

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is not caused by high-risk HPV strains but by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: Caused by high-risk HPV strains, particularly HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. Anal carcinoma: Also associated with high-risk HPV strains, including HPV 16.

 

Option C. Oropharyngeal carcinoma: Linked to high-risk HPV strains, notably HPV 16.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11) and not by the high-risk strains associated with cancers such as cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 563

choices.text: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice

questions.text: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice

 

Patients with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas, not the body develop jaundice. This is due to obstruction of the biliary tract.

 

Etiology of pancreatic carcinoma

 

  1. Heavy cigarette smokers have higher incidence than the non-smokers.
  2. Diet with high total caloric value and high consumption of animal proteins and fats is related to higher incidence of pancreatic cancer. Obesity is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
  3. Chemical carcinogens: Individuals exposed to β-naphthylamine, benzidine and nitrosamines have higher incidence of cancer of the pancreas.
  4. Diabetes mellitus: Patients of long-standing diabetes mellitus have a higher incidence.
  5. Chronic pancreatitis patients are at increased risk.
  6. H. pylori infection has been reported to have association with pancreatic cancer.
  7. Genetic factors have been found to have association with pancreatic cancer e.g. its occurrence in first-degree relatives in 10% cases, occurrence in certain hereditary syndromes (Lynch, FPC, HNPCC).

 

Obstructive jaundice is more often and early in the course of disease in cases with carcinoma head of the pancreas (80%), and less often in cancer of the body and tail of the pancreas (as they do not impinge on the biliary duct)

 

Two features are characteristic of pancreatic cancer:

 

  • Highly invasive (even “early” invasive pancreatic cancers extensively invade peripancreatic tissues)
  • Elicits an intense non-neoplastic host reaction composed of fibroblasts, lymphocytes, and extracellular matrix (called a “desmoplastic response”).

 

Dense stromal fibrosis accompanies the invasive cancer, and there is a proclivity for perineural invasion within and beyond the organ. Lymphatic and large vessel invasion are also commonly seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cigarette smoking is a risk factor: Directly linked to higher incidence rates of pancreatic carcinoma.

 

Option C. They elicit an intense desmoplastic response: Refers to the fibroblastic proliferation in the stroma surrounding the tumor, a hallmark of pancreatic cancer.

 

Option D. Perineural invasion is common: Indicates the aggressive nature of pancreatic cancer, with frequent invasion of nerves by cancer cells, contributing to pain and complex management challenges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While pancreatic carcinomas are generally associated with intense desmoplastic responses and perineural invasion, jaundice is specifically linked more with carcinoma at the head of the pancreas rather than the body or tail.

questions.text: Low transferrin saturation is seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Low transferrin saturation is indicative of inadequate iron within the body to fully saturate transferrin, which is the main protein in the blood that binds to iron and transports it throughout the body. This condition is a hallmark of iron deficiency anemia, where there is a decreased level of total body iron.

 

Transferrin Saturation (%) = (Serum Iron / Total Iron-Binding Capacity) × 100

 

  • Normal: ~20–45%
  • Low: Indicates not enough iron bound to transferrin
  • High: Indicates excess circulating iron

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemochromatosis: Incorrect because this is characterized by increased iron levels in the body, typically leading to high transferrin saturation.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: Incorrect because this is a genetic disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, not primarily associated with iron deficiency.

 

Option D. Megaloblastic anemia: Incorrect as this anemia type is usually due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, not iron.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low transferrin saturation is a significant marker for diagnosing iron deficiency anemia, reflecting a shortfall in available iron for red blood cell production.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a bone marrow aspirate having the finding as shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic myeloid leukemia

 

The image shows a characteristic cell known as a Gaucher cell, identifiable by its distinctive "crumpled tissue paper" or "wrinkled" cytoplasm appearance and blue staining.

 

 

Gaucher cells are lipid-laden histiocytes seen in Gaucher disease, but similar cells, called pseudo-Gaucher cells, can also be found in hematological malignancies, particularly in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). In CML, the presence of pseudo-Gaucher cells is a response to increased cellular turnover and abnormal lipid metabolism, making this finding more associated with CML than with other forms of leukemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute myeloid leukemia: While AML may show abnormal blast cells in the bone marrow, it is not typically associated with Gaucher or pseudo-Gaucher cells.

 

Option B. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia: ALL is characterized by lymphoblasts and does not typically present with pseudo-Gaucher cells in the bone marrow.

 

Option D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia: CLL involves mature lymphocytes, and pseudo-Gaucher cells are not a typical finding in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudo-Gaucher cells, characterized by a crumpled cytoplasm appearance, are often seen in chronic myeloid leukemia due to increased cellular turnover and abnormal lipid metabolism

choices.text: There is enzymatic digestion of cellular contents
It is associated with adjacent inflammation

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about apoptosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasma membrane remains intact  

 

The plasma membrane remains intact in apoptosis.

 

Apoptosis literally means falling-off in Greek. It is a pathway of programmed cell death.

 

Apoptotic cells break up into fragments called apoptotic bodies. These apoptotic bodies have intact plasma membrane but altered structures. Hence, they are subjected to phagocytosis without eliciting inflammation.

 

Key Features of Apoptosis:

 

  • Cell shrinkage: The cell becomes smaller in size.
  • Chromatin condensation and nuclear fragmentation (called pyknosis and karyorrhexis).
  • Formation of apoptotic bodies: The cell fragments into small, membrane-bound vesicles.
  • Phagocytosis without inflammation: Apoptotic bodies are recognized and engulfed by macrophages or nearby cells.
  • Plasma membrane remains intact during the entire process, preventing leakage of contents and avoiding inflammation.

 

Necrosis is an unprogrammed form of cell death that includes:

 

  • Enzymatic digestion
  • Adjacent inflammation
  • Karyolysis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is enzymatic digestion of cellular contents: This occurs in necrosis, not apoptosis.

 

Option B. Karyolysis is present: Karyolysis is a feature of necrosis, not apoptosis. In apoptosis, the nucleus fragments in an orderly manner.

 

Option D. It is associated with adjacent inflammation: Inflammation is characteristic of necrosis due to the release of cellular contents, but apoptosis avoids this through the containment of cell contents within intact membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 59

choices.text: T cell rich B cell lymphoma

questions.text: A young male presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. The biopsy of the lymph node showed RS cells with vague nodule formation and a background of reactive T-lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, LCA, EMA and negative for CD15 and CD30. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nodular Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL)

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).

 

Axial group (cervical) lymphadenopathy and along with the L&H variant of Reed-Sternberg cells is characteristic.

 

RS cells are neoplastic giant cells. In NLPHL, the cells have vague nodular formation. Immunophenotyping is positive for CD20 (B cell-associated), LCA (CD45), EMA (epithelial marker), and negative for CD15 (monocyte or macrophage-associated) and CD30 (activation marker).

 

 

 

  • TYPES OF RS CELLS:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Sclerosis - Hodgkin Lymphoma: This subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma (CHL) typically shows RS cells that are positive for CD15 and CD30 but negative for CD20, which is the opposite of what is seen in NLPHL.

 

Option B. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): CLL is characterized by small, mature-looking lymphocytes in the blood and bone marrow, not by the presence of RS cells or the nodular pattern seen in NLPHL.

 

Option C. T cell rich B cell lymphoma: This is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that could show a nodular pattern, but it lacks the characteristic L&H cells and the immunophenotypic profile seen in NLPHL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nodular Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL) is characterized by the presence of L&H cells, vague nodular formation, and a specific immunophenotypic profile (CD20+, CD45+, EMA+, CD15-, CD30-), which differentiates it from classical Hodgkin lymphoma and other lymphomas.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions, inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, is characterized by the presence of large platelets and Döhle bodies in neutrophils? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. May-Hegglin Anomaly

 

Explanation: 

 

May-Hegglin anomaly is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder characterized by the presence of large platelets (thrombocytopenia) and Döhle bodies in neutrophils. Döhle bodies are small, blue-gray inclusions found in the periphery of neutrophil cytoplasm. They are composed of rough endoplasmic reticulum. This condition is classified under qualitative disorders of platelet function, specifically within the category of storage pool disorders that affect platelet function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alder-Reilly bodies - These are large, dark-purple granules found in neutrophils and other leukocytes in patients with mucopolysaccharidosis. This is not associated with large platelets and is not autosomal dominant.

 

Option B. Mucopolysaccharidosis - This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down glycosaminoglycans. It is typically autosomal recessive and characterized by Alder-Reilly bodies in leukocytes, not Döhle bodies or large platelets.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome - This is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by partial albinism, recurrent infections, and large peroxidase-positive granules in neutrophils. It is not associated with large platelets or Döhle bodies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

May-Hegglin anomaly is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia with large platelets and Döhle bodies (blue-gray cytoplasmic inclusions) in neutrophils, representing a distinct qualitative platelet function disorder.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the Pediatrics OPD with the complaints of several episodes of melena. On physical examination, there was eczematous rash over the skin with multiple red pin-point hemorrhagic spots. His Hemogram reveals low platelet count and normal RBC and WBC counts. What is the next best investigation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) WASP gene mutation

 

The clinical symptoms of the patient (recurrent Melena, eczema and red pin-point hemorrhagic spots) are pointing towards the diagnosis of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome. It occurs due to WASP gene mutation.

 

So Next best step would be to analyze for WASP mutation (Chromosome Xp).

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by –

 

  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent bleeding (Melena, Epistaxis or Hematemesis)
  • Low Immunity, Recurrent Infections, Eczema
  • Low IgM and high IgA & IgE
  • Normal thymus but reduced T-cells in blood

 

The only treatment for this condition is Bone Marrow Transplantation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-platelet antibodies: While these are relevant in conditions like immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), they are not the primary investigation for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option C. Bone marrow biopsy: This can be used to assess marrow function but is not specific for diagnosing Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option D. Electron microscopy: Although useful in some hematological disorders, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome should be suspected in a pediatric patient with thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent bleeding episodes, and the next best step is to investigate for a WASP gene mutation.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 439-440

questions.text: NARP syndrome is a? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mitochondrial function disorder

 

NARP syndrome - Neuropathy Ataxia Retinitis Pigmentosa syndrome is described as a mitochondrial function disorder.

 

NARP syndrome is due to a point mutation of the mitochondrial ATPase-6 gene. Most individuals with NARP have a specific MT-ATP6 genetic change in 70 percent to 90 percent of their mitochondria. NARP syndrome is inherited from the mother (maternal inheritance) because only females pass mitochondrial DNA to their children.

 

It has 2 phenotypes:

 

  • NARP
  • Maternally inherited Leigh syndrome (MILS)

 

It is characterized by moderate, diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy and symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia on MRI. The severity of the syndrome corresponds to the mutant mitochondrial DNA load in the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosomal storage disorder: Lysosomal storage disorders result from defects in lysosomal function, leading to the accumulation of undigested macromolecules. Examples include Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher disease. NARP syndrome is not related to lysosomal function.

 

Option C. Glycogen storage disorder: Glycogen storage disorders involve defects in the metabolism of glycogen, leading to its accumulation in tissues. Examples include Pompe disease and McArdle disease. NARP syndrome is not a glycogen storage disorder.

 

Option D. Golgi body transport disorder: Disorders of the Golgi apparatus involve defects in protein and lipid processing and trafficking. Examples include congenital disorders of glycosylation. NARP syndrome is not related to Golgi body transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NARP syndrome is a mitochondrial function disorder caused by a point mutation in the mitochondrial ATPase-6 gene, leading to a spectrum of neurological and retinal symptoms.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 2572

questions.text: All of the following are associated with massive splenomegaly except: (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aplastic anemia

 

All the above are associated with massive splenomegaly except aplastic anemia.

 

Aplastic anemia is characterized by pancytopenia (a reduction in red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) due to the failure of the bone marrow. A key feature of aplastic anemia is the absence of splenomegaly. In fact, the presence of splenomegaly in a patient with pancytopenia often argues against the diagnosis of aplastic anemia.

 

There are several potential causes of splenomegaly:

 

  1. Liver disease (cirrhosis, hepatitis): Parenchymal liver disease causes increased vascular pressure leading to an increase in spleen size.
  2. Hematologic malignancies (lymphomas, leukemias, myeloproliferative disorders): Neoplastic cells cause infiltration of the spleen leading to splenomegaly.
  3. Venous thrombosis (portal or hepatic vein thrombosis): This leads to an increase in vascular pressure leading to splenomegaly.
  4. Splenic congestion (venous thrombosis, portal hypertension, congestive heart failure).
  5. Cytopenias (Immune thrombocytopenic purpura, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, immune-mediated neutropenia, Felty syndrome): Immune-mediated destruction of red blood cells, white blood cells or platelets lead to functional splenomegaly
  6. Splenic sequestration (pediatric sickle cell disease, hemolytic anemias, thalassemias).
  7. Acute or chronic infection (bacterial endocarditis, infectious mononucleosis, HIV, malaria, tuberculosis, histiocytosis, abscess).
  8. Connective tissue diseases (systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, Adult-onset Still's disease, and some familial autoinflammatory syndromes).[4][5]
  9. Infiltrative disorders (sarcoidosis, amyloidosis, glycogen storage diseases).
  10. Splenic sequestration (pediatric sickle cell, hemolytic anemias, thalassemias).
  11. Focal lesions (hemangiomas, abscess, cysts, metastasis).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure. This results in pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia). Splenomegaly is characteristically absent; if it is present, the diagnosis of aplastic anemia should be seriously questioned. Similarly, splenomegaly is also never seen in cases of ITP.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg. 1239, 1173

questions.text: What blood group should be given to a patient with Bombay blood group? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oh

 

The Bombay blood group, also known as the Oh phenotype, is one of the rarest blood groups in the world. It was discovered in 1952 by Dr Y.M. Bhende.

 

Individuals with this blood group lack the H antigen, which is a precursor to the A and B antigens found on the red blood cells of most individuals. The absence of the H antigen means that even blood type O, which normally has the H antigen, is not compatible with individuals who have the Bombay phenotype.

 

People with the Bombay blood group produce anti-H antibodies in addition to anti-A and anti-B antibodies. This means that they cannot receive blood from any of the common blood types (A, B, AB, or O), as all of these contain the H antigen and would lead to a severe transfusion reaction.

 

The only blood that can be safely transfused into a person with the Bombay blood group is blood from another Bombay blood group donor, which is denoted as Oh.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AB: Individuals with blood group AB have both A and B antigens. This blood group would not be compatible with a Bombay blood group recipient, as it would cause a severe transfusion reaction due to the presence of H antigen.

 

Option B. O positive: Blood group O positive still has the H antigen, even though it lacks A and B antigens. Transfusing O positive blood into a Bombay blood group individual would also lead to a transfusion reaction.

 

Option D. O negative: Like O positive, O negative blood has the H antigen and would not be suitable for a Bombay blood group recipient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bombay blood group (Oh phenotype) is extremely rare, and individuals with this blood type can only receive blood from another Bombay blood group donor due to the absence of the H antigen and the presence of anti-H antibodies.

questions.text: Which of the following factor is involved in the extrinsic pathway? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VII

 

Factor VII participates in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

The prothrombin time (PT) assay is done to assesses the function of the proteins in the extrinsic pathway- Factors VII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B, C, & D. Factor VIII, IX, and XI participate in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

Factor VIII is a protein involved in the intrinsic pathway and its function is assessed by the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor VII is involved in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, and its function can be assessed by the prothrombin time (PT) assay.

questions.text: All of the following are crosslinking fixatives except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methanol

 

Methanol is not a crosslinking fixative. It is a dehydrant coagulant fixative.

 

 

Compound fixatives are mixtures of reagents. Eg: alcoholic formalin fixes tissues in two ways i.e firstly, by adding covalent hydroxymethyl groups and crosslinking proteins and secondly, by coagulation and dehydration.

 

Crosslinking fixatives, on the other hand, work by forming covalent bonds between proteins and other molecules, stabilizing the tissue structure and preserving the morphology for microscopic examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutaraldehyde: A crosslinking fixative that forms stable covalent bonds between proteins, commonly used in electron microscopy.

 

Option B. Formaldehyde: Another crosslinking fixative, often used in light microscopy, that preserves tissues by forming crosslinks between proteins.

 

Option D. Osmium tetroxide: A crosslinking fixative used primarily in electron microscopy to preserve and ultrastructural visualization of cell membranes, as an additive for post-fixation after glutaraldehyde.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol is a dehydrant coagulant fixative and does not function as a crosslinking fixative like glutaraldehyde, formaldehyde, or osmium tetroxide.

questions.text: If DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, which gene causes cell cycle arrest? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) p53

 

  • Tumor suppressor gene causes cell cycle arrest (to provide time for DNA repair) and apoptosis (if DNA cannot be repaired). Acts mainly through p21 to cause cell cycle arrest. Causes apoptosis by inducing the transcription of pro-apoptotic genes such as BAX. Levels of p53 are negatively regulated by MDM2 through a feedback loop.
  • p53 is required for the G1/S checkpoint and is a main component of the G2/M checkpoint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rb: The Rb (retinoblastoma) protein is another tumor suppressor that plays a role in regulating the cell cycle. Rb controls the progression from the G1 to S phase by binding to and inhibiting E2F transcription factors. While Rb is critical for cell cycle regulation, it does not directly mediate the response to DNA damage like p53.

 

Option B. MYC: The MYC gene is a proto-oncogene that promotes cell proliferation by driving the expression of genes necessary for cell growth and division. It does not cause cell cycle arrest in response to DNA damage; instead, its dysregulation is often associated with uncontrolled cell proliferation.

 

Option D. K-RAS: K-RAS is a proto-oncogene involved in cell signaling pathways that regulate cell growth and survival. Mutations in K-RAS can lead to uncontrolled cell division and are implicated in many cancers. However, K-RAS does not have a direct role in DNA damage response or cell cycle arrest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The p53 gene is a critical tumor suppressor that causes cell cycle arrest in response to DNA damage, providing time for DNA repair or triggering apoptosis if the damage is irreparable.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, pg 527

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnea. Mitral stenosis with left atrial hypertrophy is seen. Vegetations present on the mitral valve were excised. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given HE image? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatic valvular disease

 

The given image depicts Aschoff's body, which is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease. During acute Rheumatic Fever (RF), focal inflammatory lesions are found in various tissues. Distinctive lesions occur in the heart, called Aschoff bodies, which consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to ovoid nuclei in which the chromatin is disposed in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”) and may become multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Infective endocarditis is characterized by large, friable vegetations composed of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms, which would not exhibit the Aschoff bodies seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Myxoma: Myxomas are benign tumors of the heart that typically present as a gelatinous mass, and they do not feature Aschoff bodies or the inflammatory response seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that can affect the heart but does not produce the Aschoff bodies characteristic of rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Aschoff bodies, characterized by foci of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and Anitschkow cells, is pathognomonic for rheumatic valvular disease and indicates a history of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page no – 1044

questions.text: A young man underwent a surgery on his chest after a trauma an year ago and has developed a lesion as shown. Which of the following is a probable diagnosis in the patient? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keloid

 

The image and clinical history are indicative of a keloid, which is a type of raised scar that grows excessively and extends beyond the original wound boundaries.

 

Keloid:

 

  • Definition: Keloids are overgrowths of scar tissue that develop around a wound, usually after the wound has healed. They are benign and result from an overproduction of collagen.
  • Appearance: Keloids are raised, thick, and can be pink, red, or dark in color. They often grow larger than the original wound and do not regress over time.
  • Location: Commonly occur on the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks but can appear anywhere on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign tumors made up of blood vessels. They usually appear as red or purple marks and are often present at birth or develop shortly after.

 

Option C. Normal scar: A normal scar typically lies flat against the skin and does not extend beyond the boundary of the original wound. It is usually lighter in color compared to keloids.

 

Option D. Hamartoma: Hamartomas are benign, focal malformations that resemble neoplastic tissue but grow at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. They do not typically present as raised scars.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloids are characterized by an excessive overgrowth of scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound, often appearing thick and raised. They are more common in areas such as the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks. The clinical image and description provided align with the diagnosis of a keloid.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with fever and lymph node enlargement whose tissue biopsy image is provided here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

The biopsy image provided shows the characteristic features of a granulomatous inflammation with the presence of Langhans giant cells. Langhans giant cells are multinucleated cells formed by the fusion of macrophages, and they are commonly seen in granulomas associated with tuberculosis. These cells have a distinctive arrangement of nuclei in a horseshoe or ring shape, which is a hallmark of tubercular granulomas.

 

In this clinical scenario, the patient presents with fever and lymph node enlargement (lymphadenopathy), which, along with the biopsy findings, strongly suggests a diagnosis of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis is a common cause of granulomatous inflammation, particularly in regions where the disease is endemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hodgkin lymphoma: This is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, which have a distinctive "owl's eye" appearance. These cells are not present in the biopsy image provided.
