Option C. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis also causes granulomatous inflammation but typically does not show caseation necrosis or Langhans giant cells. Non-caseating granulomas are more typical of sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. Secondaries: This refers to metastatic cancer involving the lymph nodes. The biopsy image does not show the characteristic features of metastatic cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langhans giant cells, with their horseshoe-shaped nuclei, are a characteristic finding in granulomas associated with tuberculosis, making this the most likely diagnosis in a patient with fever and lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A child presents with bilateral proptosis. Which investigation will help you in arriving at a diagnosis of chloroma? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Peripheral smear

 

Chloroma or granulocytic sarcoma is an extramedullary manifestation of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a localized tumor forming mass occurring in the skin or orbit due to local infiltration of the tissues by leukemic cells. The tumor is greenish in appearance due to the presence of myeloperoxidase.

 

The diagnosis of AML is made by a combination of routine blood picture and bone marrow examination, coupled with cytochemical stains and other special laboratory investigations.

 

The best investigation among the given options would be a peripheral blood smear which shows the following-

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelets: While platelet count can be abnormal in AML, it is not the primary diagnostic tool for chloroma.

 

Option C. Hb concentration: Hemoglobin concentration might be reduced in AML due to anemia, but it is not specific for diagnosing chloroma.

 

Option D. Leucocytic count: Leukocyte count can be elevated, normal, or low in AML, but it does not specifically help diagnose chloroma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peripheral blood smear is the key investigation to diagnose chloroma, revealing the presence of myeloblasts, which are indicative of acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortan pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, page no - 1154

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was diagnosed with intussusception and is taken up for surgery. The surgeon found multiple polyps and sent the resected section for histopathology. The image is given below. What is the type of lesion? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hamartomatous polyp

 

The image and clinical scenario point towards a hamartomatous polyp, particularly because of the patient's young age and the finding of multiple polyps. Hamartomatous polyps are generally solitary lesions but can be multiple in certain syndromes, such as Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and juvenile polyposis syndrome, which are more common in children and adolescents.

 

Hamartomatous polyps are benign, disorganized growths of tissue that are normally found in the location where they arise. In the context of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, these polyps are associated with an increased risk of intussusception due to their size and location in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubulo-villous adenoma: This type of adenoma has both tubular and villous features and is typically found in older adults, with a higher risk of malignant transformation.

 

Option C. Villous Adenoma: These are the most dangerous types of adenomas due to their higher potential for malignancy, but they are usually seen in older patients and have a distinctive villous histological appearance.

 

Option D. Hyperplastic polyp: Generally benign and more common in adults, hyperplastic polyps are typically located in the distal colon and rectum and are not associated with intussusception or multiple polyps in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1557

questions.text: Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders has a high chance of catalase positive organisms causing infections?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex. This defect impairs the ability of phagocytes to produce reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for killing certain bacteria and fungi. As a result, individuals with CGD are particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms, which can neutralize hydrogen peroxide and thus evade destruction by the impaired phagocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgE syndrome: Also known as Job syndrome, this disorder is characterized by high levels of IgE, recurrent skin abscesses, pneumonia, and characteristic facial features. It is not specifically associated with increased infections by catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Bruton disease: Also known as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, this condition affects B cell development, leading to low levels of immunoglobulins and increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, but not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency. While patients have an increased risk of infections, the susceptibility to catalase-positive organisms is not as pronounced as in CGD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic granulomatous disease is associated with a high risk of infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex, which impairs the killing of these organisms by phagocytes.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease

 

Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.

 

On light microscopy, characteristic feature is no apparent abnormality in the glomeruli except for slight increase in the mesangial matrix at the most.

 

 

By electron microscopy, the most characteristic feature of the disease is identified which is diffuse flattening of foot processes of the visceral epithelial cells (podocytes) and, hence, the name foot process disease or podocytopathy.

 

In contrast to other types of GN, no deposits are visible, and the GBM is normal. No complement or immunoglobulin deposits are detected using immunofluorescence microscopy (nil deposit disease).

 

It's also seen in other diseases like membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. These diseases are also known as podocytopathies because they affect podocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroid resistant glomerulonephritis: This term is more of a clinical description rather than a specific pathological diagnosis. Steroid-resistant cases can include various glomerulonephritis types such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which also shows podocyte effacement but is not the classic example of it.

 

Option C. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): RPGN is characterized by crescent formation in the glomeruli and is associated with severe glomerular damage and rapid loss of kidney function. It does not specifically show effacement of podocyte foot processes as its primary feature.

 

Option D. Chronic glomerulonephritis: Chronic glomerulonephritis encompasses various forms of long-standing glomerular diseases leading to chronic kidney damage. It is associated with glomerular sclerosis and interstitial fibrosis but not specifically with podocyte foot process effacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Effacement of podocyte foot processes is the characteristic feature of minimal change disease (MCD), which presents with nephrotic syndrome and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy but diffuse foot process flattening on electron microscopy.

choices.text: Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position
Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the procedure done using the instrument given in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contraindicated if platelet count <40,000

 

The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not a contraindication, and platelet transfusion can be performed if clinically warranted prior to the procedure, commonly performed if platelet counts are below 20,000 cells/microliter.

 

 

Indications of bone marrow biopsy:

 

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia
  • Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias
  • Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin, suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections, or granulomatous diseases

 

Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy:

 

  • Severe hemophilia
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Severe bleeding disorders

 

Procedure for bone marrow biopsy:

 

Prone or lateral position is chosen for the procedure. Posterior superior iliac spine is identified. After disinfection and local anesthesia, the patient is asked to inhale slowly through the nose and exhale slowly through the mouth to relieve anxiety. The needle is inserted and rotated on its axis.

 

On reaching the desired depth, the stylet is removed and needle is advanced. The needle is rotated in the opposite direction to loosen the specimen. It is then withdrawn using the same rotational movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breath holding is required: This is true for minimizing patient movement during the procedure.

 

Option C. Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position: This is true and allows for flexibility depending on the patient's condition and biopsy site.

 

Option D. Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease: This is true and one of the key indications for bone marrow biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A platelet count of <40,000 is not an absolute contraindication for bone marrow biopsy, as platelet transfusion can be performed to mitigate bleeding risk.

 

Source - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559232/

choices.text: Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
PGI2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level
Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fever? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IL-1 is an endogenous pyrogen

 

Fever is a common symptom of many illnesses, and it is an important defense mechanism of the body. It is often associated with infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Pyrogens are substances that cause fever.

 

IL-1 (interleukin-1) is an endogenous pyrogen, meaning that it is a substance produced by the body that induces fever. It is produced by activated immune cells such as macrophages and monocytes in response to infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. IL-1 acts on the hypothalamus to increase the set point of the thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature.

 

  • Endogenous pyrogens, such as prostaglandins, IL-1, and TNF
  • Exogenous pyrogens, which are bacterial lipopolysaccharides. They cause endogenous pyrogens to be released from leukocytes (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) actually reduce fever by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins, which are involved in the process of fever. Prostaglandins are produced by cells in the hypothalamus in response to pyrogens (fever-inducing substances), and they increase the set point of the hypothalamic thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature. NSAIDs inhibit the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is required for the synthesis of prostaglandins, thereby reducing fever.

 

Option B. PGI2 (prostaglandin I2): PGI2 (prostaglandin I2) is not responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level.

 

Option D. Histamine: Histamine is not directly involved in the process of fever, although it is involved in the process of inflammation. Histamine is a chemical mediator that is released by mast cells and other immune cells in response to injury or infection, and it causes dilation of blood vessels and increased permeability of capillaries. This leads to the characteristic redness, swelling, and heat that are associated with inflammation. However, histamine does not directly cause fever.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 68-year-old lady presents to the OPD with resting tremors, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity and postural instability. After some time she died due to respiratory failure following pneumonia. Which of the following is expected to be seen in his brain biopsy? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described is the characteristic of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder affecting the central nervous system. The cardinal features of Parkinson's disease mentioned in the question are:

 

  1. Resting tremors: Tremors that occur when the affected body part is at rest and disappear with voluntary movement. These are often described as "pill-rolling" tremors.
  2. Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement and difficulty initiating movements.
  3. Cogwheel rigidity: A type of rigidity characterized by jerky, ratchet-like resistance to passive movement of a joint, resembling the clicking of a cogwheel.
  4. Postural instability: Impaired balance and coordination, leading to an increased risk of falls.

 

Parkinson's disease is caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta of the midbrain, leading to a deficiency of dopamine in the nigrostriatal pathway. The hallmark histopathological finding in Parkinson's disease is the presence of Lewy bodies in the affected neurons.

 

Lewy bodies are eosinophilic, round to elongated intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of aggregated proteins, primarily alpha-synuclein. They are considered the pathological hallmark of Parkinson's disease and other related disorders, collectively known as synucleinopathies.

 

 

The patient's death due to respiratory failure following pneumonia is a common complication in advanced stages of Parkinson's disease, as the disease progression can lead to impaired swallowing and increased risk of aspiration pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Negri bodies: These are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in the neurons of animals and humans infected with rabies virus. They are not associated with Parkinson's disease.

 

 

Option C. Hirano bodies: These are eosinophilic, rod-shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions found in the neurons of patients with neurodegenerative disorders, particularly Alzheimer's disease. They are not specific to Parkinson's disease.

 

 

Option D. Heinz bodies: These are intracellular inclusions found in red blood cells of individuals with various hemolytic anemias, such as glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. They are not related to Parkinson's disease or other neurodegenerative disorders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy bodies are the characteristic histopathological finding in the brain of patients with Parkinson's disease. Their presence, along with the clinical triad of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and rigidity, confirms the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A patient reports to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and pallor. Investigations indicated hemoglobin of 5.9 g/dL, increased RDW, increased total iron binding capacity, and low ferritin. The peripheral smear shows microcytosis. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms of fatigue and pallor, which are common findings in anemia. The investigations reveal a low hemoglobin level of 5.9 g/dL, indicating the presence of anemia. The increased red cell distribution width (RDW) suggests anisocytosis, or variation in the size of red blood cells.

 

The increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC) and low ferritin levels indicate a deficiency in iron stores. Additionally, the peripheral smear shows microcytosis, which means the presence of small, hypochromic red blood cells. These findings are characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic anemia is incorrect because these patients typically have an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) due to the premature destruction of red blood cells and the release of larger, immature cells into the circulation.

 

Option C. Megaloblastic anemia is incorrect because it is characterized by the presence of large, macrocytic red blood cells, rather than the small, microcytic cells seen in this case.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic anemia is incorrect because it is typically associated with elevated ferritin levels due to increased iron storage, whereas this patient has low ferritin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low hemoglobin, increased RDW, increased TIBC, low ferritin, and the presence of microcytic red blood cells on peripheral smear.

questions.text: Clonorchis sinensis is associated with which type of cancer? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis, also known as the Chinese liver fluke, is a parasitic worm that infects the bile ducts of the liver. Chronic infection with Clonorchis sinensis is a well-known risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma, which is a type of cancer that occurs in the bile ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular cancer: This is commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B and C infections, cirrhosis, and aflatoxin exposure, not typically with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option C. Gastric cancer: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, dietary factors, and genetic predisposition, not with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option D. Urinary bladder cancer: Often linked to smoking, occupational exposures, and Schistosoma haematobium infection (another type of parasitic worm), not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opisthorchis viverrini is the new name of Clonorchis sinensis. It is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Humans acquire the infection by eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish containing the metacercariae (infective stage).

 

Chronic infection leads to:

 

  • Inflammation
  • Hyperplasia of the biliary epithelium
  • Fibrosis
  • Malignant transformation → Cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kawasaki disease

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.

 

KAWASAKI DISEASE MNEMONIC

 

CRASH & Burn

 

  • Conjunctivitis (non-purulent)
  • Rash
  • Adenopathy (cervical and commonly unilateral)
  • Strawberry tongue
  • Hands (palmar erythema/ swelling)
  • Burn (fever lasting at least 5 days or more)

 

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction.

 

Rx: Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Option D. Henoch-Schönlein purpura is an acute, systemic, immune complex-mediated, leukocytoclastic vasculitis. It is characterized by a clinical triad of palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), abdominal pain, and arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is characterized by a persistent fever, erythematous and polymorphous rash, edema of hands and feet, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. It primarily affects children under 4 years old and can lead to serious coronary artery complications if not treated appropriately.

questions.text: Which of the following represents maximum amplitude in Thromboelastography? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelet

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a test that measures the viscoelastic properties of blood as it clots under low shear conditions, mimicking sluggish venous flow. The maximum amplitude (MA) on a TEG tracing represents the final strength of the clot and is predominantly determined by the number and function of platelets and fibrin interaction.

 

  • Platelets play a crucial role in forming the solid clot structure, which is reflected by the MA. Thus, the maximum amplitude in TEG is directly associated with platelet function and quantity.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intrinsic and Option C. Extrinsic: These terms refer to different pathways of the coagulation cascade, not directly to the maximum amplitude in TEG.

 

Option D. vWD: von Willebrand Disease affects platelet adhesion due to deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, but the maximum amplitude is a function of platelet interaction with fibrin, not directly of vWD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum amplitude in Thromboelastography represents platelets. TEG is a non-invasive test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot.

questions.text: All of the following are true about neutrophil extracellular trap except:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phagocytosis is enhanced

 

Explanation:

 

Phagocytosis is enhanced: This statement is incorrect. NET formation does not directly enhance phagocytosis. Instead, it is a distinct mechanism where the neutrophil traps and kills pathogens extracellularly, without engulfing them through phagocytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are a defense mechanism employed by neutrophils to trap and kill extracellular pathogens. During NET formation, neutrophils undergo a process called NETosis, which involves chromatin decondensation and the release of DNA along with antibacterial enzymes into the extracellular space. This forms a mesh-like structure that can trap and kill bacteria.

 

Option A: Induced by sepsis: True. NETs are induced by various stimuli, including sepsis. In septicemia-like conditions, the presence of pathogens triggers the formation of NETs as a response to the infection.

 

Option C: Higher risk of SLE: True. NET formation also has some negative consequences. The exposure of nuclear antigens during NETosis can lead to an increased risk of developing autoimmune disorders, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The nuclear antigens released during NET formation can be recognized as "self" by the immune system, leading to the production of autoantibodies and the development of SLE.

 

Option D: Affected cell does not survive: True. In NET formation, the neutrophil undergoes a form of cell death called NETotic cell death. The affected neutrophil does not survive the process of NETosis, as it involves the release of its cellular contents, including DNA and enzymes. This process is sometimes referred to as "beneficial suicide" because the neutrophil sacrifices itself to create the extracellular trap that can capture and kill pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps are induced by sepsis, increase the risk of developing SLE due to exposure of nuclear antigens, and result in the death of the affected neutrophil, but they do not enhance phagocytosis.

questions.text: Alzheimer type II astrocytes are not typically found in: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Alzheimer’s disease

 

Explanation: 

 

Alzheimer type II astrocytes are not found in Alzheimer's disease, despite the confusing similarity in names. These specialized astrocytes are characterized by enlarged, pale nuclei with prominent nucleoli and margination of chromatin. They develop in response to metabolic insults, particularly hyperammonemia. Alzheimer's disease instead shows neurofibrillary tangles, amyloid plaques, and neuritic plaques as its characteristic pathological findings, along with diffuse cerebral atrophy affecting the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatic encephalopathy - This condition is characterized by the presence of Alzheimer type II astrocytes. These astrocytic changes occur in response to elevated ammonia levels that cannot be properly metabolized due to liver dysfunction, resulting in cerebral toxicity.

 

Option C. Wilson's Disease - This inherited disorder of copper metabolism affects both the liver and brain. The liver damage leads to increased ammonia levels, which can cause formation of Alzheimer type II astrocytes in the brain as a secondary phenomenon.

 

Option D. Urea Cycle Disorders - These genetic disorders impair the body's ability to eliminate ammonia, leading to hyperammonemia. The elevated ammonia affects the brain and causes the development of Alzheimer type II astrocytes as a pathological response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Despite their name, Alzheimer type II astrocytes are not found in Alzheimer's disease but are instead characteristic of metabolic encephalopathies associated with hyperammonemia, such as hepatic encephalopathy, Wilson's disease, and urea cycle disorders.
